title: 3 Tough Questions You Need to Ask Your Money Manager Today
text:
Reprint 
NEW YORK ( TheStreet ) -- When was the last time you spoke to your money manager? 
If you have a 401(k), an IRA, or own shares of a mutual fund, you are an investor. And there's a pretty good chance that your money managers -- whether big box financial corporation, mutual fund, or stockbroker -- have some remarkable conflicts of interest embedded in their businesses. 
According to the White House Council of Economic Advisors , $1.7 trillion of IRA assets are invested in products that are exposed to conflicts of interest. The estimated annual cost of all of this conflicted financial advice is $17 billion. For an individual investor, the forfeiture can add up to hundreds of thousands of dollars, even millions, over the course of a lifetime. 
Of course, money managers are not bad people -- it's the system that's perverse. When you start poking around, you quickly discover that the financial industry is brimming with ludicrous business models built atop overt conflicts of interest. 
Must Read: The 15 Best S&P 500 Dividend Stocks of the Past 25 Years 
Once you know how the game is played, however, you can protect yourself and your investments from being hijacked by the system. And asking tough questions of the folks who are managing your money is the first step. Here are three questions to ask you money manager that get to the heart of just a few of the pervasive conflicts of interest that can adversely impact investors: 
1. Do you have to put my interests above your own? There are roughly 450,000 financial advisors in the U.S. and 90% of them can legally sell you products that generate higher fees for them even if they're not the best choice for you. The Department of Labor, with the support of President Obama, is trying to change this by expanding the " fiduciary standard " to a greater number of advisors. The financial industry is fighting the change tooth-and-nail, of course, and has already successfully prevented it for decades. 
The takeaway: Be wary of investment advice from anyone who doesn't adhere to the fiduciary standard. 1 of 2
